input.name: email
input.label: E-mail address
input.help-text: Add an e-mail address that researchers MAY use for reporting security issues.

input.name: tel
input.label: Phone
input.help-text: Add an e-mail address that researchers MAY use for reporting security issues.

input.name: url
input.label: URL
input.help-text: Add an web address that researchers MAY use for reporting security issues.

input.name: encryption
input.label: Encryption
input.help-text: Paste your public key here. It will appear on your domain like this: www.example.com/public-key.txt

input.name: acknowledgements
input.label: Acknowledgements
input.help-text: This directive allows you to link to a page where security researchers are recognized for their reports. The page SHOULD list individuals or companies that disclosed security vulnerabilities and worked with you to remediate the issue.

input.name: policy
input.label: Policy
input.help-text: With the Policy directive, you can link to where your security policy and/or disclosure policy is located. This can help security researchers understand what you are looking for and how to report security vulnerabilities.

input.name: signature
input.label: Signature
input.help-text:
In order to ensure the authenticity of the security.txt file you should insert your signed signature here. It will appear under www.example.org/.well-known/security.txt.sig
When it comes to verifying the authenticity of the file, it is always the security researcher's responsibility to make sure the key being specified is indeed one they trust.

input.name: hiring
input.label: Hiring
input.help-text: The "Hiring" directive is for linking to the vendor's security- related job positions.

option-set.name: expiresOptions
option-set.label: Expiry date type
option-set.help-text: Select a dynamic or static expiry date for security.txt.
